On the dimension effect of regularized linear discriminant analysis

Cheng Wanglabel=e1]chengwang@sjtu.edu.cn [ â€ƒâ€ƒ Binyan Jianglabel=e2]by.jiang@polyu.edu.hk [ School of Mathematical Sciences,
Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, 200240, China.
Department of Applied Mathematics,
The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hung Hom, Kowloon, Hong Kong.
(2018)
Abstract

This paper studies the dimension effect of the linear discriminant analysis (LDA) and the regularized linear discriminant analysis (RLDA) classifiers for large dimensional data where the observation dimension pğ‘p is of the same order as the sample size nğ‘›n. More specifically, built on properties of the Wishart distribution and recent results in random matrix theory, we derive explicit expressions for the asymptotic misclassification errors of LDA and RLDA respectively, from which we gain insights of how dimension affects the performance of classification and in what sense. Motivated by these results, we propose adjusted classifiers by correcting the bias brought by the unequal sample sizes. The bias-corrected LDA and RLDA classifiers are shown to have smaller misclassification rates than LDA and RLDA respectively. Several interesting examples are discussed in detail and the theoretical results on dimension effect are illustrated via extensive simulation studies.

1 Introduction

Discriminant analysis that aims to allocate objects into one of the predefined classes has been an important topic in statistical learning and data analysis. Modern data is frequently featured by complex structures such as high dimensionality. In the past decades, extensive research has been done to address new challenges of high dimensionality in discriminant analysis. In particular, due to its simplicity, optimality (Anderson, 2003), and promising performance in real data analysis (Hand, 2006), the linear discriminant analysis (LDA) classifier has received more and more attention for classifying data of very large dimension under certain sparsity assumptions (Cai and Liu, 2011; Mai, Zou and Yuan, 2012; Fan, Feng and Tong, 2012). In this paper, we will focus on the general case where no sparsity assumption is assumed and study the effect of dimensionality on the performance of LDA and the regularized LDA (Friedman, 1989). For simplicity, we shall focus on the two-class classification problem.

The issue of dimension effect, or more specifically, the effect that a diverging dimension pğ‘p would brought to classical statistical inference (Bai, Liu and Wong, 2009), has been studied in several statistical problems in the literature. Bai and Saranadasa (1996) first studied the dimension effect of Hotellingâ€™s T2superscriptğ‘‡2T^{2} test by deriving the explicit power under local alternatives. Bai, Liu and Wong (2009) and ElÂ Karoui (2010) considered the dimension effect of Markowitzâ€™s portfolio. For LDA, when the dimension pğ‘p is assumed to be fixed, many works have been done to study the asymptotic of the misclassification rate by studying the properties of Wishart distribution. For a diverging pğ‘p, a seminal work by Bickel and Levina (2004) showed that when p/nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘ğ‘›p/n\to\infty, LDA tends to random guessing. Shao etÂ al. (2011) proved that when pâ€‹logâ¡p/nâ†’0â†’ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘›0p\sqrt{\log{p}}/\sqrt{n}\to 0, LDA is consistent in that the error rate of sample LDA tends to the oracle Bayes error rate. Other related works that handle variations of LDA (for example, quadratic discriminant analysis etc.) can also be found in Saranadasa (1993), Cheng (2004) and Li and Yao (2016), among others. On the other hand, when pğ‘p is large, regularization method is commonly used to reduce the dispersion of the sample covariance matrix; see for example Chen etÂ al. (2011) for the study of the regularized Hotellingâ€™s T2superscriptğ‘‡2T^{2} test and Ledoit and Wolf (2004) for regularized estimation in Markowitzâ€™s portfolio. Regularization procedure has also been widely applied in many other statistical analysis in current high dimensional literature; see for example Cai, Liu and Luo (2011), BÃ¼hlmann (2013) and Wang and Leng (2016). For discriminant analysis, the regularized LDA (RLDA) was proposed and studied in Friedman (1989) and Guo, Hastie and Tibshirani (2007). Recently, Zollanvari and Dougherty (2013, 2015) studied the misclassification error rate of RLDA with the motivation to estimate this error rate and moreover, they did not provide explicit expressions for the rate. Dobriban and Wager (2018) analyzed the predictive risk of ridge regression and regularized discriminant analysis and derived some explicit formulas. However, the results were based on the random effects hypothesis which is a strong assumption.

Among these existing literatures, the problem of how the high dimensionality would affect the classification accuracy of LDA and RLDA when the observation dimension pğ‘p is of the same order as the sample size nğ‘›n is still not well understood and in this work we provide a comprehensive analysis of the misclassification error rates under mild conditions. Built on properties of the Wishart distribution, we will first study the dimension effect of LDA (Section 2) under the assumption that p/nâ†’yâˆˆ(0,1)â†’ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¦01p/n\rightarrow y\in(0,1). In the general case where p/nâ†’yâˆˆ(0,âˆ)â†’ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¦0p/n\rightarrow y\in(0,\infty), using recent results in random matrix theory, we provide a systematic study on the dimension effect of the RLDA in Section 3. Overall, this paper aims at providing theoretical studies on the dimension effect of LDA and RLDA, from which we gain insights of how the increasing dimension affects the classification accuracy of LDA and RLDA. Following is a summary of the contributions of our work:

  • â€¢

    For LDA, we study the effect of the sample means and the sample covariance matrix respectively. Interestingly, our results show that the dimension effect brought by the sample means would introduce some bias to LDA, which would be further amplified by the effect brought by the sample covariance matrix. Motivated by these observations, a bias correction is proposed to improve the classification accuracy.

  • â€¢

    For RLDA, we derive the closed form of the error rates under general cases. Dobriban and Wager (2018) studied a similar question under random effect which is a strong condition. We relax this condition and consider a general case which includes random effect as a special case. Similar to LDA, a bias corrected RLDA is proposed to reduce the bias brought by the dimension effect that improves the classification performance.

  • â€¢

    To study the dimension effect of RLDA, the key question is to study the asymptotic limits of the moments of a class of random matrices and their random quadratic forms involved of the population means. The former one is studied by Ledoit and PÃ©chÃ© (2011), Chen etÂ al. (2011) and our previous work Wang etÂ al. (2015). When the population means satisfy some special structures such as the eigenvector structures in Bai, Miao and Pan (2007) or the random effect of Dobriban and Wager (2018), the limits of quadratic forms are the same as the moments. By studying the limits of these moments, Dobriban and Wager (2018) derived the dimension effect of RLDA under the random effect assumption. For general cases, the asymptotic of the random quadratic forms are much more challenging. Bai, Liu and Wong (2011) derived results for an identity matrix. ElÂ Karoui and Holger (2011) provided a tool to study the limits of the quadratic forms. Based on the methods of ElÂ Karoui and Holger (2011), we develop explicit results for the dimension effect of RLDA under mild conditions.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. We study the dimension effect of LDA when p/nâ†’yâˆˆ(0,1)â†’ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¦01p/n\rightarrow y\in(0,1) in Section 2. Dimension effect of RLDA is provided in Section 3. To better understand the dimension effect of RLDA and verify our theoretical results, we conduct several interesting examples in Section 4 and simulations in Section 5. All technical details are relegated to the Appendix.

2.3 Dimension effect of LDA

Theorems 2.1 and 2.2 show the explicit results for the sample means and the sample covariance from which we can see the explicit price we pay for the estimation. Now, we present the result for LDA as follows.

Theorem 2.3.

Assuming p/njâ†’yjâˆˆ(0,âˆ),j=1,2formulae-sequenceâ†’ğ‘subscriptğ‘›ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—0ğ‘—12p/n_{j}\to y_{j}\in(0,\infty),~{}j=1,2 and y=defy1â€‹y2/(y1+y2)<1superscriptdefğ‘¦subscriptğ‘¦1subscriptğ‘¦2subscriptğ‘¦1subscriptğ‘¦21y\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\mbox{{\tiny def}}}}{{=}}y_{1}y_{2}/(y_{1}+y_{2})<1, we have

RLDAâ€‹â†’ğ‘â€‹12â€‹âˆ‘j=12Î¦â€‹(âˆ’Î”2+(âˆ’1)jâ€‹(y1âˆ’y2)2â€‹Î”2+y1+y2â€‹1âˆ’y).subscriptRLDAğ‘â†’12superscriptsubscriptğ‘—12Î¦superscriptÎ”2superscript1ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¦1subscriptğ‘¦22superscriptÎ”2subscriptğ‘¦1subscriptğ‘¦21ğ‘¦\displaystyle\mbox{R}_{\text{LDA}}\overset{p}{\to}\frac{1}{2}\sum_{j=1}^{2}\Phi\left(-\frac{\Delta^{2}+(-1)^{j}(y_{1}-y_{2})}{2\sqrt{\Delta^{2}+y_{1}+y_{2}}}\sqrt{1-y}\right). (2.6)

Note that the term on the right hand side of (2.6) correspond to the misclassification rate within class 1 and class 2 respectively. LDA has different classification performance on the two classes when y1â‰ y2subscriptğ‘¦1subscriptğ‘¦2y_{1}\neq y_{2}. From the proof of Theorem 2.1 we can see that this is due to the estimation bias of intercept part in LDA. On the other hand, from (2.5) we learn that the effect from the sample covariance matrix would result in a multiplication factor 1âˆ’y1ğ‘¦\sqrt{1-y}. Interestingly, we show that when both sample means and sample covariance matrix are used as in LDA (2.3), the bias introduced by the sample means was further amplified by the multiplication factor 1âˆ’y1ğ‘¦\sqrt{1-y}.

To investigate the bias of LDA, we consider the classifier,

ğ•€â€‹{XTâ€‹Snâˆ’1â€‹(XÂ¯1âˆ’XÂ¯2)+Î±>0}.ğ•€superscriptğ‘‹Tsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘›1subscriptÂ¯ğ‘‹1subscriptÂ¯ğ‘‹2ğ›¼0\displaystyle\mathbb{I}\left\{X^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}S_{n}^{-1}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2})+\alpha>0\right\}. (2.7)

By Proposition 2 of Mai, Zou and Yuan (2012), given the classification direction Snâˆ’1â€‹(XÂ¯1âˆ’XÂ¯2)superscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘›1subscriptÂ¯ğ‘‹1subscriptÂ¯ğ‘‹2S_{n}^{-1}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2}) in (2.7), the optimal intercept corresponding to minimum misclassification rate is given as,

(2.8)

Let RLDAcsuperscriptsubscriptRLDAğ‘\mbox{R}_{\text{LDA}}^{c} be the misclassification rate of the bias-corrected classifier (2.8). The following proposition gives the asymptotic misclassification rate of the above bias-corrected classifier.

Proposition 2.1.

Under the conditions of Theorem 2.3,

RLDAcâ€‹â†’ğ‘â€‹Î¦â€‹(âˆ’Î”22â€‹Î”2+y1+y2â€‹1âˆ’y).superscriptsubscriptRLDAğ‘ğ‘â†’Î¦superscriptÎ”22superscriptÎ”2subscriptğ‘¦1subscriptğ‘¦21ğ‘¦\displaystyle\mbox{R}_{\text{LDA}}^{c}\overset{p}{\to}\Phi\left(-\frac{\Delta^{2}}{2\sqrt{\Delta^{2}+y_{1}+y_{2}}}\sqrt{1-y}\right). (2.9)

By noticing that Î¦â€‹(x)Î¦ğ‘¥\Phi(x) is strictly convex in xâˆˆ(âˆ’âˆ,0)ğ‘¥0x\in(-\infty,0), we immediately have that the asymptotic misclassification rate of the bias corrected LDA given in (2.9) is smaller than the asymptotic misclassification rate of LDA given in (2.6). In addition, considering the linear classifier with optimal intercept,

ğ•€â€‹{XTâ€‹Snâˆ’1â€‹(XÂ¯1âˆ’XÂ¯2)âˆ’12â€‹(Î¼1+Î¼2)Tâ€‹Snâˆ’1â€‹(XÂ¯1âˆ’XÂ¯2)>0}.ğ•€superscriptğ‘‹Tsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘›1subscriptÂ¯ğ‘‹1subscriptÂ¯ğ‘‹212superscriptsubscriptğœ‡1subscriptğœ‡2Tsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘›1subscriptÂ¯ğ‘‹1subscriptÂ¯ğ‘‹20\displaystyle\mathbb{I}\left\{X^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}S_{n}^{-1}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2})-\frac{1}{2}(\mu_{1}+\mu_{2})^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}S_{n}^{-1}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2})>0\right\}.

It can be shown that the result given in (2.9) would also hold for this oracle classifier, indicating that our bias correction procedure does eliminate the bias introduced by the unequal sample sizes. Finally, we remark that bias issues in binary classification have received much attention in early literatures; see for example Chan and Hall (2009) and Huang, Tong and Zhao (2010) and the references therein. For LDA, the bias-corrected classifier (2.8) happens to be identical to formula (8) of Moran and Murphy (1979). Our motivation and interpretation provide a different view on (2.8) and theoretical justifications provided in Proposition 2.1 are also new.

In literature, to handle high dimension data, naive Bayes (Dudoit, Fridlyand and Speed, 2002; Bickel and Levina, 2004) and sparse LDA (Cai and Liu, 2011; Mai, Zou and Yuan, 2012; Fan, Feng and Tong, 2012) were proposed. For naive Bayes, the correlation between the covariates is ignored and only the diagonal elements of the sample covariance matrix are used. Sparse LDA methods assumed that the discriminant direction Î²=Î£âˆ’1â€‹(Î¼1âˆ’Î¼2)ğ›½superscriptÎ£1subscriptğœ‡1subscriptğœ‡2\beta=\Sigma^{-1}(\mu_{1}-\mu_{2}) is sparse in that only several elements in Î²ğ›½\beta are non-zero and others are either zero or close to zero. In the following remarks we provide some comparison of the LDA rule to the naive Bayes rule and sparse LDA approaches.

Remark 2.1.

For simplicity, we consider the homogeneous case where the diagonal elements of Î£Î£\Sigma equal to each other and assume that n1=n2subscriptğ‘›1subscriptğ‘›2n_{1}=n_{2}. Consider the following naive Bayes classification rule,

We can see that the performance of naive Bayes depends on the structure of Î£Î£\Sigma. When the off diagonal elements of Î£Î£\Sigma are nonzero, we would need to pay some price for wrongly ignoring the correlations. A simulation study will be conducted in Section 5, providing further numerical comparison between naive Bayes and LDA.

Remark 2.2.

For sparse LDA, we take the linear programming discriminant (LPD) rule as an example which was proposed by Cai and Liu (2011). The LPD rule estimates the discriminant direction by solving the following optimization problem,

Î²^=argâ¡minâ¡|Î²|1,subjectÂ toÂ â€‹|Snâ€‹Î²âˆ’(XÂ¯1âˆ’XÂ¯2)|âˆâ‰¤tn,formulae-sequence^ğ›½subscriptğ›½1subjectÂ toÂ subscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘›ğ›½subscriptÂ¯ğ‘‹1subscriptÂ¯ğ‘‹2subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›\displaystyle\hat{\beta}=\arg\min|\beta|_{1},~{}\mbox{subject~{}to~{}}|S_{n}\beta-(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2})|_{\infty}\leq t_{n},

where sğ‘ s is the number of non-zero elements of Î£âˆ’1â€‹(Î¼1âˆ’Î¼2)superscriptÎ£1subscriptğœ‡1subscriptğœ‡2\Sigma^{-1}(\mu_{1}-\mu_{2}). Unlike LDA, the misclassification rate of LPD not only depends on pğ‘p and nğ‘›n, but also hinge on the size of sğ‘ s. When sğ‘ s is small, LPD will achieve a good performance and even close to the Bayes rule while the dimension pğ‘p is allowed to grow exponentially in nğ‘›n. However, when the sparsity assumption is violated, it is expected that LPD will perform poor if sğ‘ s is large. Further numerical comparison will be provided in Section 5.

3 Regularized Linear Discriminant Analysis

RLDA (Friedman, 1989; Guo, Hastie and Tibshirani, 2007) was proposed to reduce the dispersion of eigenvalues of the sample covariance matrix when pğ‘p is large and overcome the singularity issue when p>nâˆ’2ğ‘ğ‘›2p>n-2. For a given tuning parameter Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0, the RLDA classifier is given as,

Î´RLDAâ€‹(X)=ğ•€â€‹{(Xâˆ’XÂ¯1+XÂ¯22)Tâ€‹(Sn+Î»â€‹Ip)âˆ’1â€‹(XÂ¯1âˆ’XÂ¯2)>0}.subscriptğ›¿RLDAğ‘‹ğ•€superscriptğ‘‹subscriptÂ¯ğ‘‹1subscriptÂ¯ğ‘‹22Tsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘›ğœ†subscriptğ¼ğ‘1subscriptÂ¯ğ‘‹1subscriptÂ¯ğ‘‹20\displaystyle\delta_{\text{RLDA}}(X)=\mathbb{I}\left\{\left(X-\frac{\bar{X}_{1}+\bar{X}_{2}}{2}\right)^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}(S_{n}+\lambda I_{p})^{-1}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2})>0\right\}.

When Snsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘›S_{n} is invertible, RLDA would reduce to LDA if Î»ğœ†\lambda is set to be zero. With one more degree of freedom to adjust the estimation of the covariance matrix, it is well known that RLDA generally poses better performance than LDA, providing that Î»ğœ†\lambda is chosen properly. 3.3 Selection of Î»ğœ†\lambda

From the perspective of applications, the RLDA can avoid the singularity problem of Snsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘›S_{n} when p>nğ‘ğ‘›p>n and provides a better performance than LDA even if p<nğ‘ğ‘›p<n. However, the performance of RLDA relies on the choice of the regularization parameter Î»ğœ†\lambda. Empirically, we can use re-sampling procedures such as cross validation to choose Î»ğœ†\lambda. However, there is little work on the theoretical analysis of these re-sampling procedures, and cross validation can be computationally expensive when both pğ‘p and nğ‘›n are large. In this section, we discuss the effect of Î»ğœ†\lambda on the misclassification error rate and provide a direct estimation of the optimal Î»ğœ†\lambda for the special cases.

By Proposition 3.2, the optimal Î»ğœ†\lambda with minimum error rate is

Î»0âˆˆargâ¡maxâ¡H1â€‹(Î»)â€‹Î”2H2â€‹(Î»)â€‹Î”2+(y1+y2)â€‹R2â€‹(Î»).subscriptğœ†0subscriptğ»1ğœ†superscriptÎ”2subscriptğ»2ğœ†superscriptÎ”2subscriptğ‘¦1subscriptğ‘¦2subscriptğ‘…2ğœ†\displaystyle\lambda_{0}\in\arg\max\frac{H_{1}(\lambda)\Delta^{2}}{\sqrt{H_{2}(\lambda)\Delta^{2}+(y_{1}+y_{2})R_{2}(\lambda)}}. (3.9)

From the definitions of H1â€‹(Î»)subscriptğ»1ğœ†H_{1}(\lambda) and H2â€‹(Î»)subscriptğ»2ğœ†H_{2}(\lambda), these parameters depend on the true structures of Î£Î£\Sigma and Î¼ğœ‡\mu and it is not easy to construct estimations for them. However, under the assumption of Proposition 3.1, the optimal Î»ğœ†\lambda has a simple form

Î»0âˆˆargâ¡maxâ¡R12â€‹(Î»)R2â€‹(Î»).subscriptğœ†0subscriptsuperscriptğ‘…21ğœ†subscriptğ‘…2ğœ†\displaystyle\lambda_{0}\in\arg\max\frac{R^{2}_{1}(\lambda)}{R_{2}(\lambda)}.

This motivates us to select Î»0subscriptğœ†0\lambda_{0} by maximizing an estimate of R12â€‹(Î»)/R2â€‹(Î»)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘…21ğœ†subscriptğ‘…2ğœ†{R^{2}_{1}(\lambda)}/{R_{2}(\lambda)}. As discussed before, R1â€‹(Î»)subscriptğ‘…1ğœ†R_{1}(\lambda) and R2â€‹(Î»)subscriptğ‘…2ğœ†R_{2}(\lambda) only depends on the eigenvalues of Î£Î£\Sigma and could be estimated by the eigenvalues of Snsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘›S_{n}. Considering a shrinkage estimation Î±â€‹(Sn+Î»â€‹Ip)âˆ’1ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘›ğœ†subscriptğ¼ğ‘1\alpha(S_{n}+\lambda I_{p})^{-1} (Kubokawa and Srivastava, 2008; Wang etÂ al., 2015) for the precision matrix Î£âˆ’1superscriptÎ£1\Sigma^{-1}, we have

Therefore, similar to Wang etÂ al. (2015), we estimate the tuning parameter by

where

Following our previous work Wang etÂ al. (2015), it could be possible to establish some theoretical analysis of the estimation Î»^0subscript^ğœ†0\hat{\lambda}_{0} under the conditions given in the formula (3.6). For general Î£,Î¼1,Î¼2Î£subscriptğœ‡1subscriptğœ‡2\Sigma,\mu_{1},\mu_{2}, theoretically it is hard to conduct such an effective estimation. Therefore, we skip the theoretical analysis of the proposed tuning parameter estimation and conduct simulations in Section 5, to compare the Î»^0subscript^ğœ†0\hat{\lambda}_{0} proposed above with the one obtained by cross validations.

4 Examples

In this section, we use several examples to illustrate the theoretical results obtained in Section 3. Î£âˆ’1/2â€‹(Î¼1âˆ’Î¼2)âˆ1pâ€‹(v1+â‹¯+vp),proportional-tosuperscriptÎ£12subscriptğœ‡1subscriptğœ‡21ğ‘subscriptğ‘£1â‹¯subscriptğ‘£ğ‘\displaystyle\Sigma^{-1/2}(\mu_{1}-\mu_{2})\propto\frac{1}{\sqrt{p}}(v_{1}+\cdots+v_{p}), (4.2)
Î£âˆ’1â€‹(Î¼1âˆ’Î¼2)âˆ1pâ€‹(v1+â‹¯+vp).proportional-tosuperscriptÎ£1subscriptğœ‡1subscriptğœ‡21ğ‘subscriptğ‘£1â‹¯subscriptğ‘£ğ‘\displaystyle\Sigma^{-1}(\mu_{1}-\mu_{2})\propto\frac{1}{\sqrt{p}}(v_{1}+\cdots+v_{p}). (4.3)

In statistics, these cases have different implications. (4.1) implies that the direct differences between the two population means, (4.2) indicates the differences after covariance standardization, and (4.3) implies that the true classification weights. Similar mean-covariance structures also arise in Cai, Liu and Xia (2014) for the testing problem H0:Î¼1=Î¼2:subscriptğ»0subscriptğœ‡1subscriptğœ‡2H_{0}:\mu_{1}=\mu_{2}. In random matrix theory, Bai, Miao and Pan (2007) considered (4.1) when studying the asymptotic property of the eigenvectors and more details can be found in their Remark 1.

and the results would exactly correspond to the cases (4.2) and (4.3), respectively.

4.3 Sparse case

In this subsection, we consider the case where

Î¼1âˆ’Î¼2âˆvk.proportional-tosubscriptğœ‡1subscriptğœ‡2subscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜\displaystyle\mu_{1}-\mu_{2}\propto v_{k}.

5 Simulations

In this section, we conduct several simulations to illustrate the results. We consider the covariance matrix structures as follows:

Î£=(Ï|iâˆ’j|)pÃ—p,Î£subscriptsuperscriptğœŒğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘ğ‘\displaystyle\Sigma=(\rho^{|i-j|})_{p\times p},

where ÏğœŒ\rho reflects the correlations between the covariates and |Ï|<1ğœŒ1|\rho|<1. For all of our simulations, we let Î¼2=0subscriptğœ‡20\mu_{2}=0 and rescale Î¼1subscriptğœ‡1\mu_{1} to control the Bayes error rate as 10%percent1010\%. Here we fix the sample size n=200ğ‘›200n=200 and all the results are based on 100 replications.

5.1 Bias correction for LDA and RLDA

When n1â‰ n2subscriptğ‘›1subscriptğ‘›2n_{1}\neq n_{2}, we propose a bias correction procedure to the intercept part for LDA and RLDA. Specially, we have

Î´LDAcâ€‹(X)=ğ•€â€‹{(Xâˆ’XÂ¯1+XÂ¯22)Tâ€‹Snâˆ’1â€‹(XÂ¯1âˆ’XÂ¯2)+nâˆ’2nâˆ’pâˆ’3â€‹(p2â€‹n1âˆ’p2â€‹n2)>0},superscriptsubscriptğ›¿LDAğ‘ğ‘‹ğ•€superscriptğ‘‹subscriptÂ¯ğ‘‹1subscriptÂ¯ğ‘‹22Tsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘›1subscriptÂ¯ğ‘‹1subscriptÂ¯ğ‘‹2ğ‘›2ğ‘›ğ‘3ğ‘2subscriptğ‘›1ğ‘2subscriptğ‘›20\displaystyle\delta_{\text{LDA}}^{c}(X)=\mathbb{I}\left\{\Big{(}X-\frac{\bar{X}_{1}+\bar{X}_{2}}{2}\Big{)}^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}S_{n}^{-1}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2})+\frac{n-2}{n-p-3}\Big{(}\frac{p}{2n_{1}}-\frac{p}{2n_{2}}\Big{)}>0\right\},

and

Î´RLDAcâ€‹(X)=ğ•€subscriptsuperscriptğ›¿ğ‘RLDAğ‘‹ğ•€\displaystyle\delta^{c}_{\text{RLDA}}(X)=\mathbb{I} {(Xâˆ’XÂ¯1+XÂ¯22)T(Sn+Î»Ip)âˆ’1(XÂ¯1âˆ’XÂ¯2)\displaystyle\bigg{\{}\left(X-\frac{\bar{X}_{1}+\bar{X}_{2}}{2}\right)^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}(S_{n}+\lambda I_{p})^{-1}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2})
+(p2â€‹n1âˆ’p2â€‹n2)1âˆ’1pâ€‹tâ€‹râ€‹(1Î»â€‹Sn+Ip)âˆ’11âˆ’pnâˆ’2+1nâˆ’2â€‹tâ€‹râ€‹(1Î»â€‹Sn+Ip)âˆ’1>0},Î»>0.\displaystyle+\left(\frac{p}{2n_{1}}-\frac{p}{2n_{2}}\right)\frac{1-\frac{1}{p}tr(\frac{1}{\lambda}S_{n}+I_{p})^{-1}}{1-\frac{p}{n-2}+\frac{1}{n-2}tr(\frac{1}{\lambda}S_{n}+I_{p})^{-1}}>0\bigg{\}},~{}\lambda>0.

Our first simulation is to show the performance of the bias-corrected LDA and RLDA. We fix n=200ğ‘›200n=200 and let n1subscriptğ‘›1n_{1} rang from 10 to 190. We set Î»ğœ†\lambda as 0 (which corresponds to LDA), 0.1 and 0.5 for p<nğ‘ğ‘›p<n and 0.1, 0.5 and 1 when pâ‰¥nğ‘ğ‘›p\geq n .The data dimension pğ‘p is set to be 100, 200 or 400. As a benchmark, we also include the linear classifier with optimal constant

Î±r=âˆ’12â€‹(Î¼1+Î¼2)Tâ€‹(Sn+Î»â€‹Ip)âˆ’1â€‹(XÂ¯1âˆ’XÂ¯2),subscriptğ›¼ğ‘Ÿ12superscriptsubscriptğœ‡1subscriptğœ‡2Tsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘›ğœ†subscriptğ¼ğ‘1subscriptÂ¯ğ‘‹1subscriptÂ¯ğ‘‹2\displaystyle\alpha_{r}=-\frac{1}{2}(\mu_{1}+\mu_{2})^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}(S_{n}+\lambda I_{p})^{-1}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2}),

which is denoted by O-RLDA. We set Î£=(0.5|iâˆ’j|)pÃ—pÎ£subscriptsuperscript0.5ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘ğ‘\Sigma=(0.5^{|i-j|})_{p\times p} and Î¼1âˆ(1,0,â‹¯,0)proportional-tosubscriptğœ‡110â‹¯0\mu_{1}\propto(1,0,\cdots,0), and all the simulation results are plotted in Figure 4. We can observe that the bias corrected RLDA (C-RLDA) achieves less misclassification rate than the original RLDA and also the performance of C-RLDA is quite close the one of RLDA with optimal constants. Specially, the first figure of Figure 4 is the results for LDA where p=100,n=200formulae-sequenceğ‘100ğ‘›200p=100,~{}n=200. We also conduct simulations for more covariance and mean structures and the results follow similar patterns.

5.2 Dimension effect of LDA, naive Bayes and RLDA

In this work, our main focus is to explicitly derive the dimension effects for LDA and RLDA. In detail, the asymptotic misclassification rate of LDA depends on the ratios p/n1,p/n2ğ‘subscriptğ‘›1ğ‘subscriptğ‘›2p/n_{1},p/n_{2} and the one of RLDA also involves the structure of the covariance the means. More details can be found in Proposition 2.1 and 3.2. In Remark 2.1, we derive the dimension effect for naive Bayes. Here, we conduct a comprehensive comparison for LDA, naive Bayes and RLDA. For Î¼1subscriptğœ‡1\mu_{1}, we consider three scenarios:

  • Case 1: Î¼1âˆ(1,0,â‹¯,0)proportional-tosubscriptğœ‡110â‹¯0\mu_{1}\propto(1,0,\cdots,0);

  • Case 2: 10 % elements of Î¼1subscriptğœ‡1\mu_{1} are from Nâ€‹(0,1)ğ‘01N(0,1);

  • Case 3: all the elements of Î¼1subscriptğœ‡1\mu_{1} are from Nâ€‹(0,1)ğ‘01N(0,1);

and for each case we still rescale Î¼1subscriptğœ‡1\mu_{1} to control the Bayes error rate to be 10%. All the results are presented in Figure 5. For each heat map of the error rate, the horizontal is the data dimension pğ‘p ranging from 10 to 190 for LDA or 400 for naive Bayes and RLDA. The vertical is the correlation ÏğœŒ\rho ranging from -0.9 to 0.9. When the data dimension pğ‘p is increased, the misclassification rates for all the classifiers also increases which is well understood. When the correlations |Ï|ğœŒ|\rho| ranges from 0 to 0.9, the performance of LDA almost has no changes and Naive Bayes gets worse and worse. For RLDA, the performance is affected by |Ï|ğœŒ|\rho|, but is less sensitive than naive Bayes.

5.3 RLDA and sparse LDA

In this part, we compare RLDA with the LPD (Cai and Liu, 2011) which is one of sparse LDA methods. The tuning parameters are chosen by 5-folds cross validation. We also include the RLDA where Î»nsubscriptğœ†ğ‘›\lambda_{n} is estimated by our method in Section 3.3 and the naive Bayes. In summary, we have four methods NB, LPD, RLDA-CV and RLDA. We control the sparsity level as

Î£âˆ’1â€‹(Î¼1âˆ’Î¼2)âˆ(rnorm(s),0,â‹¯,0);proportional-tosuperscriptÎ£1subscriptğœ‡1subscriptğœ‡2rnorm(s)0â‹¯0\displaystyle\Sigma^{-1}(\mu_{1}-\mu_{2})\propto(\mbox{rnorm(s)},0,\cdots,0);

with rnorm(s) represent sğ‘ s random variables generated independently from Nâ€‹(0,1)ğ‘01N(0,1), and in this study sğ‘ s is increased from 5 to pğ‘p. Figure 6 presents the simulation results. We observe that when sğ‘ s is small, LPD is outstanding with the least error rates and the performance becomes poorer and poorer when sğ‘ s increases, while RLDA and NB are robust to different sğ‘ s. Furthermore, we find out that the version with estimated tuning parameter is comparable to the one with cross validation. Overall, we claim that LPD is applicable to the sparse cases while RLDA is favorable to the dense cases.

7.3 Proof of Theorem 2.3

7.4 Proof of Proposition 2.1

With some simple calculation it can be shown that the misclassification rate of Î´LDAcâ€‹(X)superscriptsubscriptğ›¿LDAğ‘ğ‘‹\delta_{\rm LDA}^{c}(X) is
